comments.commentBody:
How many times would you shop at a store that ignored you when you asked for help and sold you an inferior product that you couldn't return?

That has been our experience with our government the past decade plus. Hence, people are just fed up and are now taking advantage of the only opportunity they have to get even - even if it means cutting off their nose to spite their face. How else can you explain the emergence of Trump and Bernie - populists with minimal plans to support their half-baked ideas.

However this shakes out, Congress better pay attention. Otherwise, we will be electing the Three Stooges, Scooby Doo and Laurel & Hardy during the next election cycle. Where is Tom Smothers when we need him?

Two losers, one senator and one governor, join forces to prevent election of a comedian who beats both of them as well as all the other favorites of GOP.  This is certainly the funniest campaign in generations. I hope the Hollywood is already writing a script for an Oscar-winning comedy.

Is Clinton still being investigated by the FBI? If so, it is a very chilling though that she could potentially be taken out of the race and leave Trump with an already cleared path to the White House if Bernie end up dropping out soon.

Trump will be a great presidential President - ceremonial at best.  Whom he selects to run his next Company will be the deciding factor.  We should all look forward to working for the Donald and not do anything that gets us fired - we might end up in Mexico or Canada.  Say good-bye to all of this and hello to oblivion.  And, be sure to thank a Republican along the way.
Anyone but Cruz, please! Even a boorish Republican Presidential candidate (indeed, President) would be far preferable to a zealous, reactionary, and sanctimonious ideologue.

It is abundantly clear that Ted Cruz uses the phrase "abundantly clear" too often. So what now? Let me explain it in Monty Python and the Holy Grail terms. It is abundantly clear that Ted Cruz is playing the Black Knight to Donald Trump's King Arthur. Let me tell you Ted, you've no bridge crossing to guard anymore.

I've said it since day 1 when there were 17 GOP "hopefuls" on the stage.  The field was SO DESPERATELY WEAK that it became easy for Trump to distinguish himself.  After all, how smart does a demagogue have to be against the likes of Bobby Jindal or Carly Fiorina or Ben Carson?  The entire lot was (and is) so completely pathetic that the door was not only left open for Trump but the GOP establishment laid out the red carpet for him.  They created such an ugly and divisive party that it's cannibalizing itself and watching that is the ONLY enjoyable thing about what is otherwise a joyless and embarrassing period in American history.

Which candidate will return America to greatness? Hillary is status quo with old time politics of smarmy manipulation. Trump has torn off most of Hillary's transparent facade leaving her with only a skeleton of 2 by 4's holding up her fake smile.

Trump can't wait to tear Hillary to pieces in debate exposing the authentic Hillary underneath with her agrieved sense of entitlement as the wannabe first female president. As Trump bears down, watch Hillary explode in shrill rage, yelling until she is hoarse at every Trump attack.

America desperately needs a fresh start to muster it's energy and resources for the return to respected leadership it deserves!

It is difficult for Donald Trump to win 287 out of the remaining 556 delegates in order to reach the magic number of 1237. Some of the remaining states are also in favor of Ted Cruz. I am not in favor of Ted Cruz or John Kasich but Donald Trump should have won at least 150 more delegates at this stage to lock the nomination.  I have a feeling Donald Trump will fall just short of 1237 delegates and will fail to get nominated in a contested GOP convention.

Nate got this sentence completely wrong: "those rules allowed him to amass nearly half of the pledged delegates heading into the night, despite 38 percent support";Properly analyzed, this sentence means Trump got 38% of the vote on 26 April;Nothing is further from the truth - for the first time, he broke the 60% ceiling and has more than 60% in most of the 5 states. It is a big change from before, caused by voters realizing that the Cruz-Kasich deal has unmasked them as puppets the hated establishment. Indiana and California, according to recent polls, are realizing that too. This race is over, and the GOP should focus its resources on beating Clinton instead of beating Trump. 13 million voters and 40 states (some of which were robbed of their voting rights) will have spoken for Trump by 9 July, a record in many instances. It is un-American and un-Republican to keep on ignoring the will of the overwhelming majority. It is, in fact, Fascist of the GOP-establishment to keep on attacking the clear people's choice, Trump.

Trump has momentum, as the talking heads like to say, will the Democratic Party be able to hold its own, the so-call Obama collation and stand him off? It may not be there when needed.
Obama’s tenure has been disastrous for the Democratic Party, the majority of 60 in the Senate have fallen to 46 and a substantial majority in the House of Representatives is a memory of the past. Outside the Beltway the Democrats have lost ten governorships and 900 legislative seats as well. Cause and effect too complex to guess at but it will be a hard road back. The point is just that leadership with a capital L has not been one of Obama’s strong points. Sanders and others criticisms of some of his choices are not without merit, on several levels. And it is extremely difficult to see Clinton as capable of steering up enthusiasm in the general public. Fear Trump will fade as he adeptly plays at politics by being vague on what (if any) are his policies with regard to the court appointments, regime change and other hot issues might be.
The discontent with ‘the system’ is real enough and interestingly enough Bernie’s ‘enough is enough’ is not going away.

replies.commentBody: If you think the US is fat and happy, then you are dangerously deluded. What would be your definition of "unhappy"?

Under what definition of the word "happy" are you basing your statement on?

This nation is far, far, far from happy. People in bastions of wealth like Los Angeles, New York, Scottsdale (me) and others feel secure, but the vast disparity between the 0.1% and the average American is so great that revolution is not too far off. Keep living in your dream world and depending upon violence (the police state we live in is maintained with violence) and revolution is what we will have.

Hillary is the candidate of Goldman. Trump is the candidate of the angry and disposed center. If Trump wins, we might have a chance, as the country might reject his totalitarianism and right this ship, but if Hilary wins, we are all doomed. The status quo will continue a bit longer, but in the end, the revolution will burn that much brighter and the shock troops the elite depend upon will turn their weapons on them rather than the classes from whence they come.

This sort of hysterical hyperbole is precisely why those at or near the center, and even reasonable elements among the left, have abandoned the guilt culture that seeks to to bleed dry Western civilization and give our people's wealth and strength away to the rest of this dying world. Please post more and post often. You are doing the Lord's work.

comments.commentBody: This story reads like the narrative of a nightmare. I've never understood so well how a fascist can come to power, At least the German people had the excuse of being ravaged by war. Our nation is fat and happy. Trump voters could care less about the millions of refugees Europe is absorbing and the millions of immigrants here; they just want more for themselves. I resent every shallow, self interested voter for exposing America to the spectacle of Trump taking the main stage. I resent them for empowering a man who will name call during debates and encourage slug fests and riots, who will taunt world leaders on the level of a Kim Jong-il, and who will terrorize undocumented people where I live. Still, I don't dislike these silly people enough to visit a Trump presidency on them. In a 2 party system, giving a dangerous man the reins of one of them is...well...dangerous. Dare we hope Indiana or California will see the light and deny him delegates, or have the lemmings reached a fever pitch now that the cliff is in sight? Trump's final strategy seems to be to eschew interviews to avoid gaffes like the "punish women for abortions" line.

When all is said and done the final outcome of the two dynamic campaigns
of Clinton and Sanders should produce a Democratic ticket as described
below:

Hillary and Bernie as VP.
or
Bernie and Hillary as VP.

Either outcome represents the strongest ticket possible.
It allows the supporters of each candidate to back their candidate one
way or the other and the Party wins as a whole.

Democrats will support either one of these two outcomes and it is to be
hoped that Independents will do so as well.

Solidarity is the winning strategy.
There is no other option.
Any other choice will be problematic.

Either way the above final result will be unbeatable in the general
election.

comments.userDisplayName: Divorce is Good For American Economy
comments.commentBody:
The Establishment (and its servants, i.e. legislators, mainstream media, etc.) are really frightened this election cycle as standard election manipulations do not work as well as it used to, as too many voters ("under-educated white males", or educated youth, etc.) figured - at last - that mainstream Republicans and Democrats in the end never represent fundamental interests of average fellow Americans.

Today, as incompetent, naive, primitive, dangerous, extremist-labeled Americans yet again expressed their sovereign will - and now and in general election it will not be enough for Clinton and on "women-are-permanent-victims" playing spiel to "make history" and get badly compromised, millions from Wall Street and elementary women's right not observing Gulf autocracies and "depends what the word is is" Bill back into the White House.

Insulting assumptions of those who gave Jef Bush those $130+ millions assuming that the trick with Bush dynasty can be successfully repeated one more time really suggests in how low esteem these donors and GOP establishment sees fellow average Americans.

Go, Trump, go, among blinds the barely one-eyed is by far the best bet. On top of that, over the decades, Trump consistently demonstrated that he is not in any way conservative or even just "mainstream" Republican, he consistently supports women's right to choose, opposed Forbes flat tax, etc. etc.

I hope in general elections enough Bernie voters will vote Trump. That will be real change in WH!

To my fellow Democrats who are considering casting their vote for Trump -- or not voting at all if Hillary Clinton is our candidate in November: Sitting this one out is a vote for Trump, and a vote for Trump is a vote for the apocalypse. Please look beyond his anti-establishment rhetoric, which has enticed too many voters. Beneath the show is a hateful, bigoted narcissist who has no understanding that governing a country is not the same as running a business. We are not his employees. We are citizens of a democracy, and he will do all he can to destroy our collective voice and undo the good work our current President has done these past seven years.
Please show up to vote, and please support Clinton if she's our candidate. The alternative is unthinkable.

replies.commentBody:
"...don't underestimate the
number of Bernie supporters who will vote
for Trump in the general election..."

It's hard to underestimate the number because I doubt there are very many. What do Bernie voters consistently say they like about him and his policies? He's an "outsider"; his proposals on education and health care; his "stick it to the banks" attitude. I guess at least with Trump you would get one area of overlap. Who cares that he won't do any of the other stuff and represents everything you hate about the way our economy works? You just stuck it to the "establishment"! Good job!
Okay, thanks for letting us know.

How can Trump, who says almost nothing of substance on the trail, and when he does say something of substance almost always walks it back the next day, engender trust for you?  When his new senior campaign operative announces that the Trump we've all been seeing is just playing a part - like an actor -  and will soon be different?  That makes you trust him?  The mind boggles.

comments.commentBody:
Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders
have opposed the corrupt establishment and have
more in common than most media pundits realize.
If Clinton wins the nomination as it looks as if she
might, unfortunately, don't underestimate the
number of Bernie supporters who will vote
for Trump in the general election. The anti-Clinton- establishment vote is greater than you realize.
Even Trump is better in the view of many
Democrats and Independents. Clinton just
does not engender trust for us. She has way too much
negative baggage.

replies.commentBody: Yes we do, don't we ?  Sometimes not so good. Thanks for sending your post from NZ.  Good to hear from you.

comments.commentBody:
It's a fascinating election to watch from a distance. The money, the contributions, the rules around Super PACs (seems like basically there are no rules). The characters, the backstabbing, the limited debate of issues and the regular attacks on individuals. Delegates, conventions, electors - it just keeps unfolding. The absurd reality TV show that is Trump, and the only vaguely palatable GOP alternatives.

Sanders seems more grounded, rational and interested in the greater good than anyone else, though that doesn't appear to have helped him any.

If nothing else, thanks for the entertainment! USA always does it bigger and more spectacularly than anyone else!

replies.commentBody: Trump won every county in all five states tonight.  Are you suggesting all those voters are "unable to think"?  Perhaps your analysis needs to change.

comments.commentBody:
The only thing worth noting in the entire Republican nomination process is that is has served as a referendum on how shallow and limited a good portion of the voting public really is.
No thinking person who has any basic comprehension as to what government is could align themselves with this deeply flawed narcissist. He is a con man and an entertainer with the subtlety of an anvil.
It appears that a good many people want to be entertained rather than grapple with the complex and nuanced problems facing our nation.
Thankfully the rest of the nation will galvanize itself and defeat Trump and every candidate associated with him. The thinking majority will have rescued America from the lunes that have held the rest of us hostage.
It all works out.

replies.commentBody: "American prestige"? What are you talking about? The US government is known throughout the world to be utterly corrupt. Your politicians are controlled by big business interests - "lobbying" is a progressive term  for bribery. Cruz/Obama/Clinton are not interested in what the people think, they are interested in promoting their business or ideological agendas. Everyone can see this, everyone acknowledges it and that is why Trump is in the White House, where he will  restore American prestige as a by-product of actually responding to the wishes of the electorate as its first ever lobby-free president. Crooked Hillary is facing disgrace and were she to get the White House, would create a massively embarrassing impeachment process when her chickens come home to roost. But, she cannot win against Trump even were it not likely she will be indicted well before the presidential election.

comments.commentBody: Going into the home stretch with Ted Cruz as the 'alternative' has only ensured a Trump win.  It is a sure blow to American prestige to see Trump as an actual presidential candidate.  Hopefully we can recover a measure of it by a definitive rebuke of everything he represents when Hillary soundly defeats him.

replies.commentBody: and the US can go bankrupt four times.

Not sure his whining about electoral college would be able to be heard over the whining by democrats concerning gerrymandering etc.

Of course you include the lie about an obstructionist congress as though its true. The repeating of the lie, however doesnt make it true.

Hillary Clinton made 100,000 on a 1,000 dollar investment in cattle futures and was postioned the wrong way. Every analysis of her trading concluded it was fraudulent. This was her first scandal from the 80's. Then they just piled up. Always skirting rules and employing a strategy of describing her accusers of politically driven witch hunters. Im a vietnam veteran who worked in the pentagon for 14 years. No one Ive ever worked with set up their own email server. No one. But the clintons had a scheme to channel foreign money to their CGI and then use the fund for both charitable goals and developing a very well funded political machine. Emails would reveal such manipulation, so they kept it out of auditors eyes. Republicans are not angels. Trump is not the best guy - but to excoriate trump when you have a very ethically challenged candidate in hillary clinton is being incredibly obtuse.
Excuse me, but when did that cattle futures thing happen? Ever heard of "statute of limitations?" If that's the best you've got, you've thrown away your case.

comments.commentBody:
Trump will make a great president.

No more illegal aliens. They drive up the cost of housing in major cities. New York metro area alone has about 500K of them.

No more one sided trade deals. Bring manufacturing jobs back to the US.

No more paying for Europe, Saudi Arabia, S. Korea, Japan and other's defense. They can pay they owe way for a change. No wonder European loves socialism they're always on the receiving end courtesy of the US taxpayer.

Shrink the federal government. Any organization that size has 10% fat at least.

Any Democrat can crush Donald Trump or any other GOP candidate, and become impossible to stop down ticket, too, by adopting the platform that Bernie Sanders is still competing to make the party's. Check out the last sentence of his 4/26/16 concession statement:

"I congratulate Secretary Clinton on her victories tonight, and I look forward to issue-oriented campaigns in the 14 contests to come.

I am proud that we were able to win a resounding victory tonight in Rhode Island, the one state with an open primary where independents had a say in the outcome. Democrats should recognize that the ticket with the best chance of winning this November must attract support from independents as well as Democrats. I am proud of my campaign’s record in that regard.

The people in every state in this country should have the right to determine who they want as president and what the agenda of the Democratic Party should be. That’s why we are in this race until the last vote is cast. That is why this campaign is going to the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia with as many delegates as possible to fight for a progressive party platform that calls for a $15 an hour minimum wage, an end to our disastrous trade policies, a Medicare-for-all health care system, breaking up Wall Street financial institutions, ending fracking in our country, making public colleges and universities tuition free and passing a carbon tax so we can effectively address the planetary crisis of climate change."

replies.commentBody: Why would anyone repeat anything after you?  Your understanding is as shallow as a puddle in a parking lot.

comments.commentBody:
Let me saying something to provoke some thinking in this NY Times echo box.

Republican voters are further along on the curve than Democrats. The key message of the past 4-8 years is that the establishment/ status quo has no interest in the welfare of the common folk. The mainstream media/ lobbyists all prop up this corrupt system, and to that end, there's absolutely no difference in the "Centrist" wing of both parties. Clinton/ Bush all the same!

Republicans base voters who are less affluent got impacted earlier, and hence the middle finger to the mainstream Republican party as early as 2008-2010.

Democrats are just waking up, and hence the Bernie support base. Although some of it started to show up in 2012 in the Occupy Wall Street movement.

Repeat after me: Hillary is part of the problem, not the solution!

replies.userDisplayName: Divorce is Good For American Economy
replies.commentBody:
Agreed.

The establishment with its $130+ mil in fellow average Americans insulting ways bet on Jeff Bush, similar money bet on Hillary Clinton (the Dem version of establishment's candidate) are rightfully afraid that in these elections it might indeed be not so easy to fool enough Americans.

Trump will, of cause, while at the White House, do not intend to implement all of the on-the-trail made statements but he will be, also as a centrist, effective enough catalyst for some much needed, while not revolutionary changes, for change benefiting average Americans.

And I will bet that political correctness will, thanks to his presidential bully pulpit, be put on defensive, where it belongs.

comments.commentBody: Hillary Clinton is part of the Establishment and that is why Trump will win the election in November. People in both parties are sick and tired of the corrupt politics in this country. Now that Bernie Sanders is out, the Democrats have no Anti-Establishment candidate. By the way, 33 of the unbound Pennsylvania delegates have said tonight they will vote for Trump so he will get the 1237 he needs for the nomination.

replies.commentBody: The Trump cure for the Bush illness could well do away with the body politic.

comments.commentBody: We should thank Trump for preventing what could have been a true failure of American democracy:Bush vs Clinton
Oh.  Joy.
